page.title: 01SHIELDAIG VILLAGE
page.content: SHIELDAIG IS A SMALL VILLAGE ON THE NORTH-WEST COAST OF SCOTLAND. THE WORD SHIELDAIG COMES FROM THE NORSE MEANING "HERRING BAY". SHIELDAIG ISLAND LIES IN FRONT OF THE VILLAGE. IT IS COVERED IN PINE TREES AND HAS BEEN GIVEN TO THE NATIONAL TRUST AS THIS IS THE MOST WESTERLY POINT OF ORIGINAL CALEDONIAN PINE FOREST IN BRITAIN. THE MOUNTAIN OF BEN SHIELDAIG HANGS OVER THE VILLAGE AND IS ALSO CLOTHED IN CALEDONIAN PINES THE VILLAGE HAS A GOOD TOURIST TRADE IN THE SUMMER, WITH THE HOTEL, TWO SHOPS, BED AND BREAKFAST AND CAMPING. THERE ARE SIX INSHORE FISHING BOATS,AND THE MEN MAINLY FISH FOR PRAWNS, CRABS AND LOBSTERS. BEHIND THE HOUSES ARE CROFTS WHERE SHEEP ARE KEPT. SHEEP ALSO GRAZE AROUND THE VILLAGE.
